conclusion: Analyzing how shadows A, B, C, and D change when the light source moves to the back right.

Object A (small dark object) casts shadow A, Object B (circular food item) casts shadow B, Object C (roll of medical bandage with a red cross) casts shadow C, and Object D (ring or bracelet) casts shadow D.

In the first image, all shadows are cast to the left and slightly forward from their respective objects, indicating the light source is positioned to the right and slightly behind the viewer's perspective.
In the second image, all shadows have shifted position to appear more directly to the left of their objects, indicating the light source has moved further behind.
The shadows appear slightly longer in the second image, suggesting the light source is now at a lower angle relative to the objects.
The shadows maintain similar sharpness, suggesting the light source remains a similar distance away, just at a different angle.
Shadow A has moved more directly to the left of object A, appears slightly longer, and maintains a similar shape.
Shadow B has moved more directly to the left of the grapefruit dessert, appears slightly longer, and maintains a similar circular projection.
Shadow C has moved more directly to the left of the medical bandage, appears longer, and maintains a similar rectangular projection.
Shadow D has moved more directly to the left of the ring, appears slightly longer, and maintains a similar circular projection.

When the light source moves to the back right, all shadows shift position to be more directly to the left of their objects, become slightly longer, and maintain similar shapes but are projected at a different angle.
The change in shadow direction confirms the light source has moved further back and to the right from the viewer's perspective.
